title: Cross-reactive neutralization of SARS-CoV-2 by serum antibodies from recovered SARS patients and immunized animals
author: Yuanmei Zhu, Danwei Yu, Yang Han, Hongxia Yan, Huihui Chong, Lili Ren, Jianwei
affiliations: NHC Key Laboratory of Systems Biology of Pathogens, Institute of Pathogen Biology
Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences and Peking Union Medical College, Beijing, China
Department of Infectious Diseases, Peking Union Medical College Hospital, Chinese
abstract: The current COVID-19 pandemic, caused by a novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, poses serious threats to public health and social stability, calling for urgent need for vaccines and therapeutics. SARS-CoV-2 is genetically close to SARS-CoV, thus it is important to define the between antigenic cross-reactivity and neutralization. In this study, we firstly analyzed 20 21 convalescent serum samples collected from SARS-CoV infected individuals during the 2003 SARS outbreak. All patient sera reacted strongly with the S1 subunit and receptor-binding domain (RBD) of SARS-CoV, cross-reacted with the S ectodomain, S1, RBD, and S2 proteins of SARS-CoV-2, and neutralized both SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 S protein-driven infections. Multiple panels of antisera from mice and rabbits immunized with a full-length S and RBD immunogens of SARS-CoV were also characterized, verifying the cross-reactive neutralization against SARS-CoV-2. Interestingly, we found that a palm civet SARS-CoV-derived RBD elicited more potent cross-neutralizing responses in immunized animals than the RBD from a human SARS-CoV strain, informing a strategy to develop a universe vaccine against emerging CoVs.

award-group.funding-source: National Natural Science Foundation of China
CAMS Innovation Fund for Medical Sciences
